newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: South African business laments Bank rate increase.
newsitem.headline: South African business laments Bank rate increase.

text.p: South Africa's key business federation Sacob lamented a one point Bank rate hike as a "severe blow" to economic prospects in the short term, and urged the government to act urgently to induce market confidence.

"While Sacob appreciates the reasons for this step, the rise in interest rates at this time will have a negative effect on business and consumer confidence, will tend to reduce sales and generally put a dampener on economic activity," it said.
The central Reserve Bank announceed earlier on Wednesday it was increasing its key Bank rate to 17 percent from 16 percent, effective from November 21.
Sacob said the move created doubts that a forecast five percent real increase in retail sales over the Christmas period would now be achieved.
Consumers and the small business sector would suffer most because of the increased cost of borrowing resulting from a rise in lending rates, Sacob added.

Given the background reasons for the Reserve Bank's decision, Sacob said the government needed to inject a greater sense of urgency into the implementation of its growth, employment and redistribution strategy (GEAR).

"Until such times as a more comprehensive package of confidence-building measures is introduced in accordance with the macro-economic strategy...there is a danger that the latest measures will prove insufficient in addressing foreign and local investor perceptions."

Sacob said progress with privatisation, deficit reduction and the removal of the remaining exchange controls in line with the macro-economic strategy was needed to counter balance of payment constraints and inflationary pressures.
